questions.text: A patient presents with a cerebellar mass and a renal tumor, along with a similar family history. Which of the following is responsible for his findings?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A – VHL

questions.text: Most characteristic finding of diabetic nephropathy?
questions.explanation: CorrectOption A.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man has been diagnosed with solid cancer of the bowel. He also experienced massive proteinuria a few months after the initial diagnosis of cancer. What do you think is the likely cause of the development of urinary findings?
questions.explanation:
Characteristic Features of Membranous Nephropathy

Feature

Description

Primary Cause

Autoantibodies against phospholipase A2 receptor (PLA2R) on podocytes (most common in idiopathic cases).

Secondary Causes

Autoimmune diseases (SLE), infections (Hepatitis B/C), drugs (NSAIDs, penicillamine), and malignancies (lung, breast, colon cancer).

Nephrotic Syndrome Features

Massive proteinuria (>3.5 g/day), hypoalbuminemia, oedema, hyperlipidemia, lipiduria.

Risk of Thrombosis

Renal vein thrombosis is a known complication.

Light Microscopy

Diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) without hypercellularity.

Electron Microscopy (EM)

Subepithelial immune deposits create a "spike and dome" appearance.

Immunofluorescence

Granular IgG and C3 deposits along the GBM.

PLA2R Antibodies

Specific for primary membranous nephropathy and helps differentiate from secondary causes.

Treatment

ACE inhibitors/ARBs (reduce proteinuria), steroids + immunosuppressants (cyclophosphamide, rituximab) for severe cases.

Prognosis

⅓ spontaneous remission, ⅓ persistent proteinuria, ⅓ progress to ESRD.

questions.text: Effacement of podocyte foot processes is seen in which of the following diseases?

A 51-year-old male patient presents with complaints of hematuria. On examination, he is normotensive and has pedal edema. Investigations reveal that the patient has no glycosuria and a creatinine level of 9. His renal biopsy finding is given below. Which of the following investigations should be done to identify the disease?
questions.explanation:
Type I RPGN

(Anti-GBM Ab-mediated)

Type II RPGN

(Immune complex-mediated)

Type III RPGN (Pauci-immune) (M/C type)

Includes:

  1. Idiopathic
  2. Goodpasture syndrome

Includes:

  1. Idiopathic
  2. Postinfectious glomerulonephritis
  3. Lupus (SLE) nephritis
  4. Henoch-Schönlein purpura
  5. IgA nephropathy

Includes:

  1. ANCA-associated
  2. Idiopathic
  3. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly Wegener granulomatosis)
  4. Microscopic polyangiitis

IF finding:

Linear/ribbon pattern (Linear GBM deposits of IgG and C3)
 

 

IF finding:

Lumpy Bumpy/ Granular/ Starry Sky/Garland Pattern (granular antibody deposits)

 

IF finding:

No deposits

Electron microscopy: RPGN causes Rupture and wRinkling of GBM

questions.text: Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is seen in which of the following conditions? HIV SLE CLL Hepatitis B
questions.explanation:
Pathology

Light Microscope

Electron Microscope

Immunofluorescence

Type I MPGN

Mesangial proliferative or membranoproliferative patterns of proliferation; GBM thickening and Splitting.

(Double-contour or tram track appearance).

Subendothelial and mesangial deposits.

IgG ++ C3 (C1q ++ C4 may also present)

Type II MPGN (Dense Deposit Disease)

Dense intramembranous deposits.

C3; no C1q or C4

Membranous Nephropathy

Diffuse capillary wall thickening.

Subepithelial deposits.

Granular IgG and C3; diffuse

Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)

Focal and segmental sclerosis and hyalinosis.

Effacement of foot processes; epithelial denudation.

Focal; IgM + C3 in many cases

questions.text: What type of urinary casts would you expect in a patient diagnosed with Fabry’s disease?
questions.explanation:
Renal Cast Type

Condition Associated

Images

Hyaline casts

Normal conditions, Fever, Pregnancy

Muddy Brown casts

Acute tubular necrosis

Waxy casts

Chronic renal failure

Fatty casts

Nephrotic syndrome

RBC casts

Glomerulonephritis

WBC casts

Pyelonephritis, interstitial nephritis

Epithelial casts

Renal epithelial injury

Broad casts

Chronic renal disease

questions.text: A pediatric patient presents with cola-coloured urine, high blood pressure, and periorbital oedema. Laboratory tests reveal a creatinine level of 2.5 mg/dL, which rises to 4.5 mg/dL after 3 weeks despite treatment. What electron microscopic finding is most likely in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Pathological findings in PSGN

Grossly

Kidneys appear speckled or mottled due to numerous small haemorrhages (Flea-bitten appearance).

Light microscopy

Hypercellular glomeruli are caused by infiltration by leukocytes (neutrophils and monocytes) and the proliferation of endothelial and mesangial cells.

Electron microscope

‘Subepithelial electron-dense humps’ due to immune complex deposition beneath the epithelial cells of the glomerular basement membrane.

Immunofluorescence

Characteristic 'Starry sky appearance' by immune complex deposition.

questions.text: Which of the following will increase in size on electrophoresis in Nephrotic syndrome?
A 47-year-old male with 400 ml urine output per 24 hrs. On histology, he had RPGN with Pauci immune glomerulonephritis with crescents. What is the main etiology?
questions.explanation:
Type I RPGN (Anti-GBM antibody-mediated)

Type II RPGN (Immune complex-mediated)

Type III RPGN (Pauci-immune) (M/C type)

Includes:

  1. Idiopathic
  2. Goodpasture syndrome- the presence of Anti GBM. (Option A ruled out)

Includes:

  1. Idiopathic
  2. Postinfectious glomerulonephritis
  3. Lupus (SLE) nephritis - ANA positive (Option D ruled out)
  4. Henoch-Schönlein purpura
  5. IgA nephropathy

Includes:

  1. ANCA-associated
  2. Idiopathic
  3. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly Wegener granulomatosis)
  4. Microscopic polyangiitis

IF finding:

Linear/ribbon pattern (Linear GBM deposits of IgG and C3)

IF finding:

Lumpy Bumpy/ Granular/ Starry Sky/Garland Pattern (granular antibody deposits)

IF finding:

No deposits

Electron microscopy: RPGN causes Rupture and wRinkling of GBM

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient has proteinuria . Looking at the immunofluorescence image below , what is the diagnosis ?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option D - Lupus Neph

  Immunofluorescence finding
Lupus nephritis Granular deposits of IgG, IgA, IgM, C3, and C1q throughout the glomeruli
Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis Granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 along the glomerular basement membrane
Good pasture syndrome Linear deposits of IgG along the glomerular basement membrane
